oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Military pass for William Ferguson and John Branham

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: United States -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865; Tennessee -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865; Military Passes; Military Orders
oai_dc:dc.dc:relation: Camp Walker Sept. 10th 1861 Privates Wm Ferguson & John Branham of Co. K. Walker Legion have permission to pass through the country between [Q r ci ities] & Chappawamsie – Keeping out of sight of the river for the purpose of preparing a map of certain designated localities to be used by me. Wm B Bate Col Comig “Walker Legion” Tenn Vols.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Orders signed by Colonel William B. Bate permitting William Ferguson and John Branham of the Walker Legion (2nd Tennessee Infantry) to pass through the country, keeping out of sight of the river, for the purpose of preparing a map of certain designated localities to be used by Colonel Bate.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Confederate States of Ameirca -- War Dept
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Orders such as these were typically issued to prevent friendly units from confusing engineers, cartographers, and scouts with Federal spies. These orders were issued by Colonel William B. Bate of the 2nd Tennessee Infantry, later a major general, who fought at First Manassas, Shiloh, Tullahoma, Chickamauga, Chattanooga, Atlanta, and the Carolinas. Bate was elected Governor of Tennessee in 1882.
